contextId.information: Here "name" refers to the entire person of God. AT: "he" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"power" or "control." The word "hand" represents the power that wicked persons use against God's people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"hand" refers to the control or power a person. This could be stated clearly. AT: "from the control of our enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: out of the hand of our enemies

contextId.information: Here the word "redemption" is used to refer to the person who would do it. AT: "the one who would redeem Jerusalem" or "the person who would bring God's blessings and favor back to Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"the seeds that fell along the path." Jesus speaks of what happens to the seeds as if he were speaking about the seeds themselves. AT: "What happens to the seeds along the path" or "The part of the parable about the seeds that fell along the path" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The ones along the path are

contextId.information: Jesus speaks of what happens to the seeds as if he were speaking about the seeds themselves. AT: "What happens to the seeds that fell among the thorns" or "The part of the parable about the seeds that fell among the thorns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The seeds that fell among the thorns

contextId.information: Jesus speaks of what happens to the seeds as if he were speaking about the seeds themselves. AT: "What happens to the seeds that fell on the good soil" or "The part of the parable about the seeds that fell on the good soil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the seed that fell on the good soil

contextId.information: "carry his cross and follow me every day." The cross represents suffering and death. Taking up the cross represents being willing to suffer and die. AT: "must obey me every day even to the point of suffering and dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take up his cross daily and follow me

contextId.information: The "heart" refers to the deepest thoughts and desires of a person. AT: "thinking about individually" or "considering in their private thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This was both a greeting and a blessing. Here "house" refers to those who live in the house. AT: "May the people in this household receive peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: May peace be on this house

contextId.information: Here "name" refers to Jesus' power and authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These all mean that a person must completely love God with all of their being. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: your heart ... your soul ... your strength ... your mind

contextId.information: This refers to everything that Jesus taught while at Martha's house. AT: "listened to the Lord teach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"kingdom" here refers to the people in it. This can also be stated in active form. AT: "If people of a kingdom fight among themselves, they will destroy their kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Every kingdom divided against itself is made desolate

contextId.information: "Satan" here is referring to the demons who follow Satan as well as to Satan himself. AT: "If Satan and members of his kingdom are fighting among themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: If Satan is divided against himself

contextId.information: The "finger of God" refers to God's power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The eye is a metonym for vision. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"eye" here is a metonym for vision. AT: "When your vision is good" or "when you see well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "eye" is a metonym for vision. AT: "When your vision is bad" or "when you see poorly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The people to whom Jesus was speaking will be held responsible for the murder of the prophets by their ancestors. AT: "Therefore, God will hold this generation responsible for all the deaths of the prophets that people have killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: This generation, then, will be held responsible for all the blood of the prophets shed

contextId.information: Here "nations" refers to "unbelievers." AT: "all people of other nations" or "all the unbelievers in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all the nations of the world

contextId.information: Here "heart" refers to a person's thoughts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"heart" here refers to the person. AT: "thinks to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"taught the people in them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

If it would be strange to address the city, you can make it clear that Jesus was really addressing the people in the city: "you people who kill the prophets and stone those sent to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who kills the prophets and stones those sent to you

contextId.information: The people of Jerusalem are described as her "children." AT: "to gather your people" or "to gather the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" refers to the Lord's power and authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jewish people sometimes avoided saying the word "God" and used the word "heaven" instead. AT: "I have sinned against God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hearts" refers to the desires of people. AT: "God understands your true desires" or "God knows your motives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

A "stroke" is the smallest part of a letter. It refers to something in the law that may seem to be the least important. AT: "than for even the smallest detail of the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: than for one stroke of a letter

contextId.information: This refers to the people in the house. AT: "my family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
His "words" refer to all that he had said. AT: "Based on what you have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" refers to power and authority. Also, "Lord" refers to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in the name of the Lord

contextId.information: The word "it" refers to the city of Jerusalem, but it represents the people who lived in that city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"from God." Jewish people avoided referring to God by his name "Yahweh." Often they used the word "heaven" to refer to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This expression refers to people exercising authority over the disciples. AT: "looked for a way to arrest Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sought to lay hands on him

contextId.information: Because Caesar was the ruler of the Roman government, they could refer to the Roman government by Caesar's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Caesar" refers to the Roman government. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"they will grab you." This expression refers to people exercising authority over the disciples. AT: "they will arrest you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they will lay their hands on you

contextId.information: The word "name" is here used to refer to Jesus himself. AT: "because of me" or "because you follow me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

God, who delivers, is spoken of as if he were the deliverance that he causes. AT: "because your deliverer is coming to you" or "because God will soon save you"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: because your deliverance is coming near

contextId.information: "God will soon establish his kingdom." AT: "God will soon rule as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the kingdom of God is near

contextId.information: "my words will never cease to exist" or "my words will never fail." Jesus uses "words" here to refer to everything he says. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my words will never pass away

contextId.information: They were to share the contents of the cup, and not the cup itself. AT: "share the wine in the cup among yourselves" or "each of you drink some of the wine from the cup" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "cup" refers to the wine in the cup. AT: "The wine in this cup" or "This cup of wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Jesus spoke of his death by referring to his blood being poured out. AT: "my blood, which is poured out in death for you" or "my blood, which will flow out of my wounds for you when I die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my blood, which is poured out for you

contextId.information: Kings sit on thrones. Sitting on a throne is a symbol of ruling. AT: "you will work as kings" or "you will do the work of kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here, the crowing of the rooster refers to a certain time of day. Roosters often crow just before the sun appears in the morning. Therefore, this refers to dawn. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
A purse is a bag for holding money. Here it is used to refer to "money." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This expression refers to people exercising authority over the disciples. AT: "arrest me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus' "word" is here used to refer to everything that he said. AT: "Jesus' words" or "what Jesus had said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the all-powerful God." Here "power" refers to his supreme authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Caesar represents the Emperor of Rome. AT: "to the Emperor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
To "come into" a kingdom means to begin to rule. AT: "begin to rule as king" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"The phrase "into your hands" refers to God's care. AT: "I entrust my spirit to your care" or "I give my spirit to you, knowing you will care for it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: into your hands I commit my spirit

contextId.information: Here "words" refers to the statement that Jesus made. AT: "remembered what Jesus said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The "heart" was considered to be what enabled a person to make decisions. AT: "your minds are slow to believe" or "you are slow to believe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and slow of heart to believe

contextId.information: Moses wrote the first books of the Bible. AT: "beginning with the writings of Moses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
His "name" here refers to this authority. AT: "with Jesus' authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
